content.definition: A form of pulmonary hypertension (WHO Group 4) caused by organized thromboembolic obstruction of the pulmonary arteries that fails to resolve after acute PE. Results in increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right heart failure. Potentially curable with pulmonary thromboendarterectomy (PTE).

clinical_features.epidemiology: Develops in 0.5-4% of patients after acute PE
pathophysiology: Failure of thrombus resolution after acute PE
Organization of thrombus into fibrous tissue
Right ventricular pressure overload and failure
diagnosis: CT pulmonary angiography: Organized thrombus, webs, bands
Right heart catheterization: mPAP ≥25 mmHg, PCWP ≤15

management.surgical_PTE: Pulmonary thromboendarterectomy - potentially curative for proximal disease

surgical_candidacy: Proximal disease (main, lobar, segmental pulmonary arteries)

clinical_pearls: Think CTEPH if dyspnea persists >3 months after acute PE
V/Q scan more sensitive than CTA for CTEPH detection
PTE is potentially curative - refer to specialized center
BPA (balloon pulmonary angioplasty) expanding for distal disease
Lifelong anticoagulation even after successful PTE

learning_objectives: Identify patients at risk for CTEPH after acute PE
Understand treatment options including PTE and BPA
